G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the “best interests of the child” standard as the controlling principle in custody cases and repeatedly characterizes it as the paramount concern. The court traces the history of the standard, reaffirms that it governs custody and visitation decisions in Massachusetts, and applies it as the governing standard in resolving the custody dispute in this case.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the impact of domestic violence on the child and the need to assess custody in light of those effects, which is consistent with a best-interests-of-the-child framework. Although the excerpt does not contain the exact phrase "paramount consideration" or a long, general statement of the best-interests standard, the court’s reasoning and reliance on statutory provisions like G.L. c. 208, § 31 make clear that custody decisions must turn on the child’s welfare, including safety from domestic violence.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. . . . We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below "fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability." . . . Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Adoption of Jill, 44 Mass. Adoption of Jill, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 491.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, Computune, Inc. (Computune), brought a complaint in the Superior Court against the defendants, Edward D. Tocio and Dorothy P. Tocio (referred to collectively as “Tocio”), seeking specific performance of a lease, which included a provision for an option to purchase land, and money damages. Tocio, in turn, filed a counterclaim seeking a declaration that (1) the lease was not in effect when Computune attempted to exercise its option to purchase, and (2) the lease had expired on September 15, 1988, relegating Computune to a tenant at will status as of that date.

Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.raw_text: Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (2004)
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that exposure to domestic violence and volatile or aggressive behavior in a household can be profoundly harmful to children and is a significant factor in determining their best interests.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly acknowledges that domestic violence, including violence witnessed by a child, is a serious and distinct harm to children and must be expressly considered in custody determinations. The court quotes and applies Custody of Vaughn’s recognition that a child who is a victim or spectator of family violence suffers a “grievous” harm, and remands specifically for findings on the effects of domestic violence on the child and its relation to the father’s fitness and the custody decision. This squarely supports the proposition that exposure to domestic violence and volatile behavior is profoundly harmful to children and a significant best-interests factor.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “In Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595, the court declared that ‘physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and ... a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.’ … Vaughn cautions, however, that witnessing domestic violence is itself a ‘grievous’ harm… Because the issue cannot be decided by implication, we remand the case for clarification of the judge’s findings on domestic violence, its effects on the child, and its relationship to the father’s ability to parent.”

The unfitness analysis focuses on sexual abuse by the father and the mother’s disbelief and lack of engagement, not on indirect exposure to domestic conflict or emotional harm from yelling or intimidation.
Adoption of Olivette, 79 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Because we have concluded that the judge correctly admitted Olivette’s allegations of sexual abuse based on his conclusion (supported by the evidence at the § 82 hearing) that they were reliable, the judge’s conclusion regarding the father’s unfitness is clearly supported. The mother contends that the evidence of her unfitness was insufficient, because there was no nexus between her disbelief of Olivette’s allegations and any resulting harm to the child. However, ‘[u]nfitness is not based solely on a parent’s affirmative conduct but partakes of an assessment of the parent’s “character, temperament, capacity and conduct.”’”}

Petition of the Dep\u2019t of Social Ser.case_name: Petitions of the Department of Social Services to Dispense With Consent to Adoption
Petition of the Dep\u2019t of Social Ser.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness, service-plan noncompliance, and procedural issues surrounding the psychotherapist–patient privilege and hospital records. It does not discuss a child’s exposure to yelling, intimidation, or physical aggression directed at others, nor does it analyze how such exposure affects emotional well-being or justify limits on contact or parenting time. Any emotional harm discussed arises from the mother’s inappropriate conversation topics and the anxiety surrounding visitation, not from witnessing violence or aggression, so the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Petition of the Dep\u2019t of Social Ser.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that, during this time, the parties did not interact well, with Mrs. B telling the children of her lack of food and money and other subjects inappropriate for young children. In one visit, the daughter held her hands over her face for one-half hour. After this visit, the daughter refused to eat and stated that she did not want any further visits with ‘that lady.’ As a result of this child’s failure to eat, her foster parents consulted a pediatrician, who diagnosed her as having anorexia. This doctor attributed the anorexia to the child’s anxiety over continued visitation with Mrs. B.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Under Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010), the Court must consider both (a) whether a material change has occurred, and (b) whether the requested change will advance the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion focuses on statutory interpretation under G.L. c. 209C and on the limits of a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal parent to return. It does not articulate a two-step standard requiring a threshold finding of material change and then a best-interests analysis; rather, it criticizes the judge for misapplying removal law (Yannas) and for intruding on the mother’s relocation decision. Any discussion of best interests appears only in the context of criticizing the lower court’s approach, not as a required dual test of material change plus best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ("If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement").

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have broad equitable powers to craft conditions on parenting time that protect children while maintaining parent–child relationships.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The case does not explicitly discuss “broad equitable powers” in those terms, but it does affirm that in custody and visitation matters the court’s overriding concern is the children’s best interests, and that this may justify limiting a parent’s time with the children even at the cost of the parent’s liberties. It upholds a significant reduction in the father’s visitation as an appropriate exercise of discretion to protect the children while recognizing the general legal value of “frequent and continuing contact” with both parents. That aligns with the idea that Massachusetts courts can craft conditions on parenting time to balance child protection and maintenance of parent–child relationships.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order.… ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have broad equitable powers to craft conditions on parenting time that protect children while maintaining parent–child relationships.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does address parenting time (visitation) in the context of removal and recognizes that visitation arrangements can and will be modified to balance the custodial parent’s interests and the child’s relationship with the noncustodial parent. However, it does not speak in terms of Massachusetts courts’ ‘broad equitable powers’ to craft conditions on parenting time; rather, it applies the statutory ‘best interests’/‘real advantage’ standard and notes that alternative visitation should be ‘reasonable.’ The case is more about relocation standards than about the scope of equitable authority to impose protective conditions on parenting time, so it only indirectly relates to the claimed proposition and does not clearly establish it.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The interests of the noncustodial parent must be considered. If that parent is unfit or has not exercised his or her rights of visitation, the judge’s problem is less difficult than in the case of a diligent noncustodial parent. The reasonableness of alternative visitation arrangements should be assessed. The fact that visitation by the noncustodial parent will be changed to his or her disadvantage cannot be controlling.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: The requested relief is consistent with the principle that the noncustodial parent’s access may be limited or conditioned when necessary to protect a child’s safety and welfare.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with legal vs. physical custody, joint legal custody, and the procedural mechanism for changing custody (requiring a complaint for modification rather than a motion). It does not discuss limiting or conditioning a noncustodial parent’s access or visitation to protect the child’s safety or welfare. The modification the SJC orders concerns the proper procedural route for custody changes, not standards for restricting a noncustodial parent’s access for child-protection reasons.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The requested relief is consistent with the principle that the noncustodial parent’s access may be limited or conditioned when necessary to protect a child’s safety and welfare.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that a noncustodial parent’s religious activities and visitation can be limited when necessary to protect the child’s best interests, including physical and emotional welfare, but emphasizes that such harm must be demonstrated and not assumed. Although the court reverses the restriction in this case for lack of evidentiary support, its reasoning accepts the underlying principle that visitation may be conditioned or curtailed when proven harmful to the child. Thus, it supports the general proposition about limiting access to protect a child’s safety and welfare, while imposing a proof requirement.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “But the ‘best interests’ of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents… However, harm to the child from conflicting religious instructions or practices, which would justify such a limitation, should not be simply assumed or surmised; it must be demonstrated in detail… It is often said that if accommodation appears necessary, that form should be sought which intrudes least on the religious inclinations of either parent and is yet compatible with the health of the child.”

Bercume v. Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “The removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents is governed generally by G. L. c. 208, § 30… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’ Second, if the real advantage test is satisfied, the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.’”

Adoption of Larry, 434 Mass. 456 (2001).proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions emphasize that even when abuse is directed toward someone other than the child, the child’s exposure to that environment is relevant to custody and visitation decisions.
Adoption of Larry, 434 Mass. 456 (2001).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns severe physical abuse directly inflicted on the child (shaken baby syndrome) and the resulting determination of parental unfitness and termination of rights. The analysis focuses on which parent may have abused the child, the mother’s inability to protect the child from the father, and her dependency on him. It does not discuss abuse directed at someone other than the child or the legal relevance of the child’s mere exposure to an abusive environment for custody or visitation, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Adoption of Larry, 434 Mass. 456 (2001).relevant_excerpt: "The judge also concluded that the mother had been unable to protect Larry from the father, and that she remained unable to protect him. ... Her willingness to protect the father, and not Larry, and to be so forgiving of the father in the face of overwhelming evidence that Larry’s head injuries were caused not by an accident, but by intentional, violent shaking for some thirty seconds, is clear and convincing evidence that she cannot protect Larry from the father."
